subject: Re: [junit] ClassPathTestCollector
msgSnippet: Just to share an experience of mine. I tried to do a class loader that will try to load all the none abstract classes that extending the TestCase in the run
messageBody:
Just to share an experience of mine.

I tried to do a class loader that will try to load all the none abstract classes that extending the TestCase in the run time but the code became too much to
write.

Then I figured out another simple way of sweeping all the testcases by following these steps.

1. Put all the test classes (mock object, test utilities, whatever other than the real code) into a separate folder (I called it 'test' and it is in the same
folder as 'src').

2. Follow a naming convention. I named all my test cases and ONLY my test cases with 'Test' followed by the class to be tested.

3. I wrote a class that will go through the 'test' folder (recursively by option) and find all the java files start with a Test, construct the full name of
the class, create a TestSuite for it and add it to the main TestSuite.

Step one will free me in naming the classes for the application, step two will make the testcase sweeping easy.

Potential risks:
1. Test class is not in 'test' directory.
2. Test class doesn't start with 'Test' or some non-testing class starts with 'Test'.
3. The source file in test directory doesn't match the ones in classes path. (This is not a big problem as along as you compile the project before you run
the test, which is the case).

It sounds a little cheap and un-safe at the first sight. But it has never caused me problems. I would think that this is the 'simplest possible that
works'.

And yes, I do have a test case for this. :)

> I'm working on a TestRunner that sweeps up all of the TestCases on the
> class path into one TestSuite and then runs it, dumping the results
> optionally to a file, System.out, or a gui. This TestRunner could then be
> used in automation and during development with a minimum of setup.
> ClassPathTestCollector does a great job of grabbing up the .class files on
> the class path, but it doesn't dip into the jars to grab those classes also.
> I'm about to write some code to add this functionality. Has anyone already
> done this? If so, could you share code, ideas, or suggestions?
